title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement nkhoshnevis@g.harvard.edu. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: CRE
text: Installing CRAN. Installing latest developing version. Import.

title: CRE
text: Data (required) y observed response/outcome vector (binary continuous). z treatment/exposure/policy vector (binary). X covariate matrix (binary continuous). Parameters (required) method_parameters list parameters define models used, including: - ratio_dis ratio data delegated discovery sub-sample (default: 0.5). - ite_method_dis method estimate individual treatment effect (ITE) discovery sub-sample (default: ‘aipw’) [1]. - ps_method_dis estimation model propensity score discovery sub-sample (default: ‘SL.xgboost’). - or_method_dis estimation model outcome regressions estimate_ite_aipw discovery sub-sample (default: ‘SL.xgboost’). - ite_method_inf method estimate individual treatment effect (ITE) inference sub-sample (default: ‘aipw’) [1]. - ps_method_inf estimation model propensity score inference subsample (default: ‘SL.xgboost’). - or_method_inf estimation model outcome regressions estimate_ite_aipw inference subsample (default: ‘SL.xgboost’). hyper_params list hyper parameters fine tune method, including: - intervention_vars Intervention-able variables used Rules Generation (default: NULL). - offset Name covariate use offset (.e. ‘x1’) T-Poisson ITE Estimation. NULL used (default: NULL). - ntrees_rf number decision trees random forest (default: 20). - ntrees_gbm number decision trees generalized boosted regression modeling algorithm. (default: 20). - node_size Minimum size trees’ terminal nodes (default: 20). - max_nodes Maximum number terminal nodes per tree (default: 5). - max_depth Maximum rules length (default: 3). - replace Boolean variable replacement bootstrapping rules generation random forest (default: TRUE). - t_decay decay threshold rules pruning (default: 0.025). - t_ext threshold define generic specific (extreme) rules (default: 0.01). - t_corr threshold define correlated rules (default: 1). - t_pvalue threshold define statistically significant rules (default: 0.05). - stability_selection Whether using stability selection selecting rules (default: TRUE). - cutoff Threshold defining minimum cutoff value stability scores (default: 0.9). - pfer Upper bound per-family error rate (tolerated amount falsely selected rules) (default: 1). - penalty_rl Order penalty rules length LASSO Regularization (.e. 0: penalty, 1: rules_length, 2: rules_length^2) (default: 1). Additional Estimates (required) ite estimated ITE vector. given, ITE estimation steps Discovery Inference skipped (default: NULL).

title: CRE
text: [1] Options ITE estimation follows: S-Learner (slearner) T-Learner (tlearner) T-Poisson (tpoisson) X-Learner (xlearner) Augmented Inverse Probability Weighting (aipw) Causal Forests (cf) Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (bart) estimates ITE provided ite additional argument, ITE estimations discovery inference skipped values estimates used instead.

title: CRE
text: One can create customized wrapper SuperLearner internal packages. following example providing number cores (e.g., 12) xgboost package shared memory system. use “m_xgboost”, instead “SL.xgboost”.

title: CRE
text: Example 1 (default parameters) Example 2 (personalized ite estimation) Example 3 (setting parameters) synthetic data sets can generated using generate_cre_dataset().
code: set.seed(9687) dataset <- generate_cre_dataset(n = 1000,                                  rho = 0,                                  n_rules = 2,                                  p = 10,                                 effect_size = 2,                                  binary_covariates = TRUE,                                 binary_outcome = FALSE,                                 confounding = "no") y <- dataset[["y"]] z <- dataset[["z"]] X <- dataset[["X"]]  cre_results <- cre(y, z, X) summary(cre_results) plot(cre_results) set.seed(9687) dataset <- generate_cre_dataset(n = 1000,                                  rho = 0,                                  n_rules = 2,                                  p = 10,                                 effect_size = 2,                                  binary_covariates = TRUE,                                 binary_outcome = FALSE,                                 confounding = "no")   y <- dataset[["y"]]   z <- dataset[["z"]]   X <- dataset[["X"]]  ite_pred <- ... # personalized ite estimation cre_results <- cre(y, z, X, ite = ite_pred) summary(cre_results) plot(cre_results) set.seed(9687) dataset <- generate_cre_dataset(n = 1000,                                    rho = 0,                                    n_rules = 2,                                    p = 10,                                   effect_size = 2,                                    binary_covariates = TRUE,                                   binary_outcome = FALSE,                                   confounding = "no") y <- dataset[["y"]] z <- dataset[["z"]] X <- dataset[["X"]]  method_params <- list(ratio_dis = 0.25,                       ite_method_dis="aipw",                       ps_method_dis = "SL.xgboost",                       oreg_method_dis = "SL.xgboost",                       ite_method_inf = "aipw",                       ps_method_inf = "SL.xgboost",                       oreg_method_inf = "SL.xgboost")  hyper_params <- list(intervention_vars = c("x1","x2","x3","x4"),                      offset = NULL,                      ntrees_rf = 20,                      ntrees_gbm = 20,                      node_size = 20,                      max_nodes = 5,                      max_depth = 3,                      t_decay = 0.025,                      t_ext = 0.025,                      t_corr = 1,                      t_pvalue = 0.05,                      replace = FALSE,                      stability_selection = TRUE,                      cutoff = 0.8,                      pfer = 0.1,                      penalty_rl = 1)  cre_results <- cre(y, z, X, method_params, hyper_params) summary(cre_results) plot(cre_results)

title: Contribution
text: project, follow tidyverse style guide.

title: Contribution
text: File names snake_case ends .R (e.g., create_matching.R) variable names small letter separate _ need (e.g., delta_n) Function names follow snake_case style (e.g., generate_data) Function names follow verb+output convention (e.g., compute_resid)

title: Contribution
text: Indentations two spaces (use tab) Place space around binary operators (e.g., x + y) Place space comma Place space # commenting avoid multiple ### put space opening closing parenthesis Place space () used , , .
code: #Acceptable: z <- x + y #Not recommended: z<-x+y # (no space) z<- x+y z<-x +y #Acceptable: a <- matrix(c(1:100), nrow = 5) #Not recommended: a <- matrix(c(1:100),nrow = 5) # (no space after comma) a <- matrix( c(1:100), nrow = 5 ) # (extra space after and before parentheses) a<-matrix(c(1:100), nrow = 5) # (no space around unary operator <- ) #Acceptable: # This is a comment #Not recommended: #This is a comment #    This is a comment (more than one space after #) ## This is a comment (multiple #) ###    This is a comment (multiple # and more than one space) #Acceptable: x <- (z + y) #Not recommended: x <- ( z + y ) # (unnecessary space) x <- (z + y ) x <- ( z + y) #Acceptible if (x > 2) {   print(x) } # Not recommended if(x > 2){   print(x) }

title: Contribution
text: Maximum line length 80 character Use explicit returns Use explicit tags documentation (e.g., @title, @description, …)

title: Testing the CRE Package

what: Installing the package directly from Github
title: Testing the CRE Package
text: project, follow successful Git Branching Model. result, develop branch updated branch developers. Use devtools::install_github install package. specify ref, install master (main) branch. Try ?CRE. open package description page help tab (assuming using RStudio).
code: library(devtools) try(detach("package:CRE", unload = TRUE), silent = TRUE) # if already you have the package, detach and unload it, to have a new install.  install_github("NSAPH-Software/CRE", ref="develop") library(CRE)

title: Testing the CRE Package
text: Run following command test package.
code: library(CRE)  # Generate sample data set.seed(1358) dataset <- generate_cre_dataset(n = 1000,                                 rho = 0,                                 n_rules = 2,                                 p = 10,                                 effect_size = 2,                                 binary_covariates = TRUE,                                 binary_outcome = FALSE,                                 confounding = "no") y <- dataset[["y"]] z <- dataset[["z"]] X <- dataset[["X"]]  method_params <- list(ratio_dis = 0.25,                       ite_method_dis = "aipw",                       include_ps_dis = TRUE,                       ps_method_dis = "SL.xgboost",                       ps_method_inf = "SL.xgboost",                       oreg_method_dis = "SL.xgboost",                       oreg_method_inf = "SL.xgboost",                       ite_method_inf = "aipw",                       include_ps_inf = TRUE,                       offset = NULL)  hyper_params <- list(intervention_vars = NULL,                      ntrees_rf = 200,                      ntrees_gbm = 200,                      node_size = 20,                      max_nodes = 5,                      max_depth = 15,                      replace = TRUE,                      max_decay = 0.025,                      type_decay = 2,                      t_ext = 0.01,                      t_corr = 1,                      t_pvalue = 0.05,                      stability_selection = TRUE,                      cutoff = 0.6,                      pfer = 1,                      penalty_rl = 1)  # linreg CATE estimation with aipw ITE estimation cre_results <- cre(y, z, X, method_params, hyper_params) summary(cre_results) plot(cre_results)

title: Interpretable Subgroups Identification through Ensemble Learning of Causal Rules
text: Identifying subgroups study population treatment exposure notably larger smaller effect outcome compared population average crucial social health sciences. estimating conditional average treatment effect (CATE) given pre-specified set covariates common approach, allows estimating causal effects subgroups specified priori researchers. package implements recently developed Causal Rule Ensemble (CRE) algorithm, flexible stable method interpretable discovery estimation heterogeneous treatment effects terms decision rules.

title: Interpretable Subgroups Identification through Ensemble Learning of Causal Rules
text: cre() function executes entire CRE algorithm utilizing data set input parameters user provides. divides study data discovery inference subsamples, generating filtering decision rules discovery subsample explain heterogeneity treatment effects. cre() uses inference subsample estimate linear decomposition Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE) terms just discovered decision rules, normal equations model ITE estimates. steps, cre() agnostic concerning method used ITE estimation. estimate Individual Treatment Effects (ITE), users can choose various methodologies vary terms speed accuracy. Several ITE estimators internally implemented (.e. AIPW, Causal Forest, Bayesian Causal Forest, Causal BART, S-Learner, T-Learner, X-Learner), customized ITE estimation can also provided input. results collected S3 object containing: number decision rules extracted step, CATE decomposition estimates corresponding uncertainty quantification, list selected parameters, predicted ITEs.

title: Interpretable Subgroups Identification through Ensemble Learning of Causal Rules
text: CRE package can used diverse theoretical practical applications long working binary exposure treatment level. example, can used education determine teaching methods effective specific student subgroups. marketing, can identify effective strategies different consumer subgroups. healthcare, can used identify patient subgroups benefit particular treatment intervention. can also used studies personalized medicine subgroup patients responds differently provided medicine. public health, CRE method applied discover subgroups vulnerable (resilient) causal effects long-term exposure air pollution mortality.

title: The 'CRE' package — CRE-package
text: health social sciences, critically important identify subgroups study population treatment notable heterogeneity causal effects respect average treatment effect. Data-driven discovery heterogeneous treatment effects (HTE) via decision tree methods proposed task. Despite high interpretability, single-tree discovery HTE tends highly unstable find oversimplified representation treatment heterogeneity. accommodate shortcomings, propose Causal Rule Ensemble (CRE), new method discover heterogeneous subgroups ensemble--trees approach. CRE following features: provides interpretable representation HTE; 2) allows extensive exploration complex heterogeneity patterns; 3) guarantees high stability discovery. discovered subgroups defined terms interpretable decision rules, develop general two-stage approach subgroup-specific conditional causal effects estimation, providing theoretical guarantees.

title: Causal rule ensemble — cre
text: Performs Causal Rule Ensemble data set response variable, treatment variable, various features.

title: Causal rule ensemble — cre
code: cre(y, z, X, method_params = NULL, hyper_params = NULL, ite = NULL)

title: Causal rule ensemble — cre
text: y observed response vector. z treatment vector. X covariate matrix (data frame). provided numerical values. method_params list parameters define models used, including: Parameters Honest Splitting ratio_dis: ratio data delegated rules discovery (default: 0.5). Parameters Discovery ite_method_dis: method estimate discovery sample ITE (default: 'aipw'). ps_method_dis: estimation model propensity score discovery subsample (default: 'SL.xgboost'). oreg_method_dis: estimation model outcome regressions estimate_ite_aipw discovery subsample (default: 'SL.xgboost'). Parameters Inference ite_method_inf: method estimate inference sample ITE (default: 'aipw'). ps_method_inf: estimation model propensity score inference subsample (default: 'SL.xgboost'). oreg_method_inf: estimation model outcome regressions estimate_ite_aipw inference subsample (default: 'SL.xgboost'). hyper_params list hyper parameters fine-tune method, including: intervention_vars: Intervention-able variables used rules generation. Use NULL include variables (default: NULL). offset: Name covariate use offset (.e. 'x1') T-Poisson ITE estimation. Use NULL offset used (default: NULL). ntrees_rf: number decision trees random forest (default: 20). ntrees_gbm: number decision trees generalized boosted regression modeling algorithm. (default: 20). node_size: Minimum size trees' terminal nodes (default: 20). max_nodes: Maximum number terminal nodes per tree (default: 5). max_depth: Maximum rules length (default: 3). replace: Boolean variable replacement bootstrapping rules generation random forest (default: TRUE). t_decay: decay threshold rules pruning. Higher values carry aggressive pruning (default: 0.025). t_ext: threshold truncate generic specific (extreme) rules (default: 0.01, range: [0, 0.5)). t_corr: threshold define correlated rules (default: 1, range: (0,+inf)). t_pvalue: threshold define statistically significant rules (default: 0.05, range: (0, 1)). stability_selection: Whether using stability selection selecting rules (default: TRUE). cutoff:  Threshold (percentage) defining minimum cutoff value stability scores (default: 0.9). pfer: Upper bound per-family error rate (tolerated amount falsely selected rules) (default: 1). penalty_rl: Order penalty rules length LASSO regularization (.e. 0: penalty, 1: rules_length, 2: rules_length^2) (default: 1). ite estimated ITE vector. given ITE estimation steps Discovery Inference skipped (default: NULL).

title: Causal rule ensemble — cre
text: S3 object containing: number Decision Rules extracted step (M). data.frame Conditional Average Treatment Effect decomposition estimates corresponding uncertainty quantification (CATE). list method parameters (method_params). list hyper parameters (hyper_params). Individual Treatment Effect predicted (ite_pred).

title: Causal rule ensemble — cre
text: intervention_vars provided, important note individual treatment effect still computed using covariates.

title: Causal rule ensemble — cre
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(2021) dataset <- generate_cre_dataset(n = 400, rho = 0, n_rules = 2, p = 10,                                 effect_size = 2, binary_covariates = TRUE,                                 binary_outcome = FALSE, confounding = "no") y <- dataset[["y"]] z <- dataset[["z"]] X <- dataset[["X"]]  method_params <- list(ratio_dis = 0.25,                       ite_method_dis="aipw",                       ps_method_dis = "SL.xgboost",                       oreg_method_dis = "SL.xgboost",                       ite_method_inf = "aipw",                       ps_method_inf = "SL.xgboost",                       oreg_method_inf = "SL.xgboost")  hyper_params <- list(intervention_vars = NULL,                      offset = NULL,                      ntrees_rf = 20,                      ntrees_gbm = 20,                      node_size = 20,                      max_nodes = 5,                      max_depth = 3,                      t_decay = 0.025,                      t_ext = 0.025,                      t_corr = 1,                      t_pvalue = 0.05,                      replace = FALSE,                      stability_selection = TRUE,                      cutoff = 0.6,                      pfer = 0.1,                      penalty_rl = 1)  cre_results <- cre(y, z, X, method_params, hyper_params) #> Loading required package: nnls #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'randomForest': #>   method      from #>   plot.margin RRF  # }

what: The Causal Rule Ensemble Crossfit — cre_crossfit
title: The Causal Rule Ensemble Crossfit — cre_crossfit
text: Performs Causal Rule Ensemble twice dataset response variable, treatment variable, various features, swapping discovery inference subsamples.

title: The Causal Rule Ensemble Crossfit — cre_crossfit
code: cre_crossfit(   y,   z,   X,   ite_method_dis,   include_ps_dis = NA,   ps_method_dis = "SL.xgboost",   or_method_dis = NA,   ite_method_inf,   include_ps_inf = NA,   ps_method_inf = "SL.xgboost",   or_method_inf = NA,   ntrees_rf,   ntrees_gbm,   min_nodes,   max_nodes,   t,   q,   rules_method = NA,   include_offset = FALSE,   offset_name = NA,   cate_method = "DRLearner",   cate_SL_library = "SL.xgboost",   filter_cate = FALSE )

title: The Causal Rule Ensemble Crossfit — cre_crossfit
text: y observed response vector z treatment vector X covariate matrix ite_method_dis method estimate discovery sample ITE include_ps_dis whether include propensity score estimate covariate discovery ITE estimation, considered BART, XBART, CF ps_method_dis estimation model propensity score discovery subsample or_method_dis estimation model outcome regressions estimate_ite_aipw discovery subsample ite_method_inf method estimate inference sample ITE include_ps_inf whether include propensity score estimate covariate inference ITE estimation, considered BART, XBART, CF ps_method_inf estimation model propensity score inference subsample or_method_inf estimation model outcome regressions estimate_ite_aipw inference subsample ntrees_rf number decision trees randomForest ntrees_gbm number decision trees gradient boosting min_nodes minimum size trees' terminal nodes max_nodes maximum size trees' terminal nodes t common support used generating causal rules matrix q selection threshold used selecting causal rules rules_method method selecting causal rules binary outcomes include_offset whether include offset estimating ITE, poisson offset_name name offset, included cate_method method estimate CATE values cate_SL_library library used cate_method set DRLearner filter_cate whether filter rules p-value <= 0.05

title: The Causal Rule Ensemble Crossfit — cre_crossfit
text: S3 object containing matrix averaged Conditional Average Treatment Effect estimates two CRE iterations

title: The Causal Rule Ensemble Crossfit — cre_crossfit
code: dataset <- generate_cre_dataset(n = 1000, rho = 0, n_rules = 2, p = 10,                                 effect_size = 2, binary = FALSE)  cre_cross_results <- cre_crossfit(y = dataset[["y"]], z = dataset[["z"]],                                   X = as.data.frame(dataset[["X"]]),                                   ite_method_dis = "bart",                                   include_ps_dis = TRUE,                                   ite_method_inf = "bart",                                   include_ps_inf = TRUE,                                   ntrees_rf = 100, ntrees_gbm = 50,                                   min_nodes = 20, max_nodes = 5,                                   t = 0.025, q = 0.8) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' #> Conducting Discovery Subsample Analysis 1 #> 411 rules (length<=15) were extracted from the first 100 trees. #> 150 rules (length<=15) were extracted from the first 50 trees. #> Conducting Inference Subsample Analysis 1 #> Conducting Discovery Subsample Analysis 2 #> 493 rules (length<=15) were extracted from the first 100 trees. #> 100 rules (length<=15) were extracted from the first 50 trees. #> Conducting Inference Subsample Analysis 2

title: Estimate the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — estimate_cate
Estimate the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — estimate_cate
text: rules_matrix rules matrix, rules_explicit list select rules terms covariate names. ite estimated ITEs. t_pvalue threshold define statistically significant rules (filter rules p-value <= t_pvalue).

title: Estimate the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — estimate_cate
text: list 2 elements: summary: data frame summarizing CATE linear decomposition: 'Rule': rule name, 'Estimate': linear contribution CATE, 'CI_lower`: lower bound 95% confidence interval estimate, 'CI_upper`: upper bound 95% confidence interval estimate, P-Value: p-value (Z-test). model: linear model CATE-ATE estimation.

title: Generate CRE synthetic data — generate_cre_dataset
code: generate_cre_dataset(   n = 1000,   rho = 0,   n_rules = 2,   p = 10,   effect_size = 2,   binary_covariates = TRUE,   binary_outcome = TRUE,   confounding = "no" )

title: Generate CRE synthetic data — generate_cre_dataset
text: n integer number represents number observations. Non-integer values converted integer number. rho positive double number represents correlation within covariates (default: 0, range: (0,1)). n_rules number causal rules. (default: 2, range: 1,2,3,4). p number covariates (default: 10). effect_size effect size magnitude (default: 2, range: >=0). binary_covariates Whether use binary continuous covariates (default: TRUE). binary_outcome Whether use binary continuous outcomes (default: TRUE). confounding continuous outcome, add confounding variables: Linear confounding "lin". Non-linear confounding "nonlin". confounding "" (default).

title: Generate CRE synthetic data — generate_cre_dataset
text: list synthetic data containing: outcome vector (y), treatment vector (z), covariates matrix (X) individual treatment vector (ite)

title: Generate CRE synthetic data — generate_cre_dataset
text: Set (binary/continuous) covariates domain (binary_covariates). Set (binary/continuous) outcome domain (binary_outcome). Increase complexity heterogeneity discovery: Decreasing sample size (n), adding correlation among variables (rho), increasing number rules (n_rules), increasing number covariates (p), decreasing absolute value causal effect (effect_size), adding linear -linear confounders (confounding).

title: Generate CRE synthetic data — generate_cre_dataset
code: set.seed(123) dataset <- generate_cre_dataset(n = 1000, rho = 0, n_rules = 2, p = 10,                                 effect_size = 2, binary_covariates = TRUE,                                 binary_outcome = TRUE, confounding = "no")

title: Generate rules — generate_rules

title: Generate rules — generate_rules
text: list rules (names).

title: Generate rules matrix — generate_rules_matrix
text: Generates rules matrix feature covariate matrix vector rules. number rows rules_matrix equal number samples X, number columns equal number rules rules_list. element rules_matrix corresponds specific data sample rule. data sample satisfies rule, corresponding element rules_matrix set 1. Otherwise, element set 0.

title: CRE 0.1.0 (2022-10-17)
text: Update examples tests functions. q hyper-parameter -> cutoff. pfer_val hyper-parameter -> pfer. select_causal_rules function -> lasso_rules_filter. t hyper-parameter -> t_anom. Separate standardization, remove filtering generate_rules_matrix function. summary.cre function describe results. min_nodes hyper-parameter -> node_size (randomForest convention). cre returns S3 object.

title: CRE 0.1.0 (2022-10-17)
text: Examples tests functions. prune_rules function discard un-predictive rules. discard_anomalous_rules function discard anomalous rules (see t_corr hyper-parameter.). discard_correlated_rules function discard correlated rules (see t_anom hyper-parameter). effect_modifiers parameter generate_rules function covariates filtering. generate_causal_rules function. Helper function SuperLearner package propensity score estimation estimate_ite_xyz. Five methods CATE estimation (poisson, DRLearner, bart-baggr, cf-means, linreg) estimate_cate function. (ps_method_dis, ps_method_inf, or_method_dis, or_method_inf, cate_SL_library) method-parameters complement SuperLearner package. cate_method method-parameter select CATE estimation method. filter_cate method-parameter estimation filtering. p parameter (generate_cre_dataset function) set number covariates. replace parameter (generate_rules function) allow bootstrapping. cre.print generic function print cre S3 object results. cre.summary generic functions summarize cre S3 object Results. check_input function isolate input checks. estimate_ite_aipw function augmented inverse propensity weighting. plot.cre generic function plot cre S3 object results. test-cre_functional.R test functionality package. stability_selection function causal rules selection.

title: CRE 0.0.1 (2021-10-20)
text: estimate_cate include two methods estimating CATE values. cre added initial checks binary outcome whether include propensity score ITE estimation. estimate_ite_xyz conduct propensity score estimation using helper function.

title: CRE 0.0.1 (2021-10-20)
text: Example generate_cre_dataset. set_logger get_logger. check_input_data function. generate_cre_dataset function generate synthetic data testing package. test-generate_cre_dataset function test. estimate_ps function estimate propensity score. estimate_ite_xbart function generate ITE estimates using accelerated BART. estimate_ite_xbcf function generate ITE estimates using accelerated BCF. analyze_sensitivity function conduct sensitivity analysis unmeasured confounding. cre function perform entire Causal Rule Ensemble method. estimate_cate function generate CATE estimates ITE estimates select rules. estimate_ite function generate ITE estimates using user-specified method (calls estimate_ite_xyz functions). estimate_ite_bart function generate ITE estimates using BART. estimate_ite_bcf function generate ITE estimates using Bayesian Causal Forests. estimate_ite_cf function generate ITE estimates using Causal Forests. estimate_ite_ipw function generate ITE estimates using IPW. estimate_ite_or function generate ITE estimates using Outcome Regression. estimate_ite_sipw function generate ITE estimates using SIPW. extract_rules function extract list causal rules randomForest GBM models. generate_rules function generate causal rule models using randomForest GBM methods. generate_rules_matrix function convert list causal rules matrix. select_causal_rules function apply penalized regression causal rules. select important ones. split_data function split input data discovery inference subsamples. take1 function create subsample indices.

title: CRE 0.0.1 (2021-10-20)
text: seed argument generate_cre_datase function.
